text: 1. Hari h , Om. There lived once S vetaketu Âru n eya (the grandson of Aru n a). To him his father (Uddâlaka, the son of Aru n a) said: ' S vetaketu, go to school; for there is none belonging to our race, darling, who, not having studied (the Veda), is, as it were, a Brâhma n a by birth only.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. Having begun his apprenticeship (with a teacher) when he was twelve years of age 1 , S vetaketu returned to his father, when he was twenty-four, having then studied all the Vedas,--conceited, considering himself well-read, and stern.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. His father said to him: ' S vetaketu, as you are so conceited, considering yourself so well-read, and so stern, my dear, have you ever asked for that instruction by which we hear what cannot be heard, by which we perceive what cannot be perceived, by which we know what cannot be known?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. 'What is that instruction, Sir?' he asked.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: The father replied: 'My dear, as by one clod of clay all that is made of clay is known, the difference 2 being only a name, arising from speech, but the truth being that all is clay;

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. 'And as, my dear, by one nugget of gold 3

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: all that is made of gold is known, the difference being only a name, arising from speech, but the truth being that all is gold?

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. 'And as, my dear, by one pair of nail-scissors all that is made of iron (kârsh n âyasam) is known, the difference being only a name, arising from speech, but the truth being that all is iron,--thus, my dear, is that instruction.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. The son said: 'Surely those venerable men (my teachers) did not know that. For if they had known it, why should they not have told it me? Do you, Sir, therefore tell me that.' 'Be it so,' said the father.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 92:1 This was rather late, for the son of a Brahman might have begun his studies when he was seven years old. Âpastamba-sûtras I, 1, 18. Twelve years was considered the right time for mastering one of the Vedas.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 92:2 Vikâra, difference, variety, change, by form and name, development, cf. VI, 3, 3.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 92:3 The commentator takes lohamani here as suvar n api n d a.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
